content: The CUS-MIL-100­(Fe) was synthesized by a previously reported hydrothermal method with certain postsynthetic modifications. In brief, 0.82 g of Fe powder and 2.06 g of H3BTC were first mixed in 80 mL of deionized water, followed by the addition of 1.14 mL of HNO3 and 0.6 mL of HF. The reactant mixture was vigorously stirred for 1 h and then transferred to a dried 100 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave. The autoclave was progressively heated to 150 °C within 8 h and maintained for 24 h. After cooling naturally, the obtained precipitate was recovered by filtration, washed sequentially by stirring in 80 °C hot deionized water for 5 h and in 60 °C hot ethanol for 3 h to remove the residual unreacted reactants and the colored impurities, and then dried in a vacuum oven at 70 °C for 12 h. Subsequently, the prepared light-orange powder was activated under vacuum conditions at 230 °C for 12 h to generate the iron CUS with mixed-valence FeII/FeIII. Finally, the resulting brown product was collected and stored in a covered glass container until needed. For comparison, the MIL-100­(Fe) was synthesized as the above hydrothermal procedure without vacuum activation treatment.
clean_text:
Synthesis of CUS-MIL-100(Fe)

The CUS-MIL-100(Fe) was synthesized by a previously reported hydrothermal method with certain postsynthetic modifications. In brief, 0.82 g of Fe powder and 2.06 g of H3BTC were first mixed in 80 mL of deionized water, followed by the addition of 1.14 mL of HNO3 and 0.6 mL of HF. The reactant mixture was vigorously stirred for 1 h and then transferred to a dried 100 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave. The autoclave was progressively heated to 150 °C within 8 h and maintained for 24 h. After cooling naturally, the obtained precipitate was recovered by filtration, washed sequentially by stirring in 80 °C hot deionized water for 5 h and in 60 °C hot ethanol for 3 h to remove the residual unreacted reactants and the colored impurities, and then dried in a vacuum oven at 70 °C for 12 h. Subsequently, the prepared light-orange powder was activated under vacuum conditions at 230 °C for 12 h to generate the iron CUS with mixed-valence FeII/FeIII. Finally, the resulting brown product was collected and stored in a covered glass container until needed. For comparison, the MIL-100(Fe) was synthesized as the above hydrothermal procedure without vacuum activation treatment.
